<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 21.17.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
strcmp(bus->name, name) reads both operands until a terminating '\0'. The code does not validate that 'name' is non-NULL and null-terminated nor that 'bus->name' is null-terminated (definition of struct metal_bus not shown). If either operand is not a pointer to a NUL-terminated buffer (for example bus->name is a fixed-size char array not guaranteed to contain a '\0', or caller passes a non-terminated buffer or NULL), strcmp can read beyond object bounds. Therefore Rule 21.17 is violated unless callers/struct invariants guarantee both strings are valid NUL-terminated, non-NULL strings.
</violation scenario>

Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.

<target_code>

int metal_bus_find(const char *name, struct metal_bus **result)
{
	struct metal_list *node;
	struct metal_bus *bus;

	metal_list_for_each(&_metal.common.bus_list, node) {
		bus = metal_container_of(node, struct metal_bus, node);
		if (strcmp(bus->name, name) == 0 && result) {
			*result = bus;
			return 0;
		}
	}
	return -ENOENT;
}
